data.title: Particle2d randomness
data.body:
Currently any randomness within the implementation doesn't work properly.
Any randomness would not take effect since the internal working of how seeds are produced for each particle made a too small of a seed for the random function to work properly.

data.title: [3.0] Make drawing polygons work again
data.body:
The code path for drawing polygons is currently commented out.
I assume @reduz has some plans for that but as it stands anythings that
needs polygon drawing like Line2D just doesn't render.

This proposes a somewhat inefficient solution but one that works and
doesn't drastically change the code.

data.title: Debugger stoped with large variable content in the breakpoint stack
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Arch Linux - ~~Godot 2.1.3~~ Godot 3.0 alpha1

**Issue description:**
<!-- What happened, and what was expected. -->

The debugger server stopped and client frazed when break point.

**Steps to reproduce:**

```gdscript
extends Control

func _ready():
	var godot_classes = {}
	var file = File.new()
	if OK == file.open("res://classes.json", File.READ):
		var json_text = file.get_as_text()
                godot_classes.parse_json(json_text)
		breakpoint
```
When the file `res://classes.json` is larger than 64KB the debugger will stoped.

data.title: Building with `verbose=no` on Windows with Visual Studio duplicates lines in standard output
data.body:
When building Godot (tested with https://github.com/godotengine/godot/commit/69bec86028f87307e549d7a2f49bbb7e2b1f3771 and Visual Studio 2017, can also be reproduced with VS 2015) with `verbose=no` passed to SCons, each compiled file will appear twice in the log. One of them will be colored and formatted, one of them won't. See below for screenshot.

![quieter_output](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/180032/26753529/db4047a8-4868-11e7-993e-f89fd0ca1f05.png)

This makes the console output less compact and readable than it ought to be.

data.title: InputEvent: Renamed "pos" property to "position"
data.body: Make the naming consistent with other classes.

data.title: Changing the tooltip delay in project settings affects the editor
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Windows 10 64bit - Godot 2.1.3 and Godot 3.0

**Issue description:**
Changing the tooltip delay in project settings will affect the editor's tooltips (after closing the project and reopening it). It should only affect the tooltips in-game.

**Steps to reproduce:**
Open any project, go to project settings and set tooltip delay to 0, then close the project and reopen it. Now all tooltips in the editor appear instantly.

data.title: Ability to selectively make engine ignore nodes from interaction (disable them in editor at run time)
data.body:
I am developing a side scroller game.

I need to disable obstacles to check interaction of character with outer bounds (walls) of the map but I couldn't find a way to make physics engine ignore obstacle nodes. When I make obstacles invisible I just get "scary invisible obstacles" :smile:   

I have to remove them and add them back for now. Adding an icon to "disable nodes" like making them invisible will help. This will speed up manual debugging and testing.

data.title: [idea] OS-less deploy
data.body:
This is not an original idea. It comes from the good 'ol '80; if you still don't know what I am talking about, take a [look at this](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_PC_booter_games)


Now, maybe "OSless" is not the correct definition for it; since there should be always a pack of software for kernel, services and drivers to run any game; but it gives pretty much the core idea of what's all about.

Obviously we talk about something that's already here: Linux's binaries of Godot... and the very bare needs Godot Engine needs to run. I am talking about the Kernel, X11, OpenGL, networking (for updates and stuff) and the input service (for keyboard, mouse, joypad etc)... everything else scraped away in order to have achieve the fastest "reboot PC directly in game"
no CUPS and its drivers, no server/services (that are not strictly related to the game engine/network)  like webcam support, dvb-t etc... hell, it doesn't even need to support other filesytems other than EXT4 and other /dev/sd* partitions and devices (also this is supposed to increase safety by sandboxing as much as possible).

**But on which media? 3.5 floppies?**
First, let me tell you something: inside my PC desktop there's NO internal Hard Disk. Everything I do on my Lubuntu runs from a USB3 pendrive (64GB)... and from there I can do everything... also I am able to pick up my usb drive and bring with me my "desktop experience" on virtually any other 64bit PC. From said pendrive I can run any virtualised Windows machine from 3.1 all the way up to 8 (10 untested due to personal disinterest).
With the world completely gone "mobile" internal disks are a structural obsolescence kept up by convenience: the only way Microsoft can claim "ownership" on your pc.

You can make your own Desktop Linux persistent USB3 pendrive... and boot the same experience on virtually any PC: bring on your old PC with integrated Intel HD and play at lower setting at  720p, or give it a try on your shiny new battlestation with a powerful R9 390X @4k at Ultra settings. Fully re-distributable open source drivers from AMD and Intel.
No need to reinstall, no need cloud storage to bring your save games
One simple usb key to boot your machine and seamlessly continue play anywhere lays a pc around.


**What's good for?**
...for developer: it's an easy and convenient way to quickly test your game on the bare hardware of random PC around the world. Deploy your game on a 2inch 32GB pen drive... and go around (with given permission) and try to boot your game anywhere. A friend of yours just bought a Nvidia GTX 2048Ti? Go there and boot your game; you can even go in a repair shop and (after asking kindly) test your game. If you're competent enough, you can even integrate your own hardware DRM ([with Namco style encryption](https://medium.com/@dropkickshell/system-n2-exposed-5395436c824d) ) and sell your game as physical usb keys.
...for gamers: plug key, play the game. Finish playing? Put the key in your pocket: the saved games  and the *whole thing* is physically there. No one can peek in the stuff you play/do any more. Lan party? You need to bring your rig only if **there are not** PC already there. If your Lan party already got PCs... you just need the key with (all) your Godot game(s).

**The OS "less" part:**
Well... obviously there's still a kernel and a collection of packages: technically still an OS, but keeping in mind there's almost "no operating" since it will be cut out all the features not related to the game runtime and safety. Good quality usb3 flash disk are capable to read at speed of 100MB/sec. It would take about ~7 seconds to transfer a common Ubuntu iso in the RAM: and this would include lot of unused stuff. A very bare bone reduced ARM Linux (with busybox) can [boot in ~300ms](http://www.makelinux.com/emb/fastboot/) 
[cut because it's too long otherwise]

data.title: Using draw_texture() with load() causes an error
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:** 2.1.3


**Issue description:**
Doing this:
```
func _draw():
    draw_texture(load("res://texture.png"), Vector2(0,0))
```
will cause an error to flood the debugger and the texture is shown completely white. **_However_**, doing this is fine:
```
var tex = load("res://texture.png")

func _draw():
    draw_texture(tex, Vector2(0,0))
```

Is this a limitation or a bug?

This is the error displayed:
```
C Error: Condition ' !elem ' is true. returned: 0
C Source: c:\projects\godot-builds\godot\core\rid.h:143
C Function: RID_Owner<struct RasterizerGLES2:Texture,0>::get
```

data.title: Remove mutex-locking from non-debug memory routines (2.1)
data.body:
since the malloc() suite is nowadays thread-safe by itself (from MSVC 2010 you don't even have a non-MT runtime and for POSIX-based OSs it's mandatory by the spec.

NOTE: _master_'s memory routines are already lockless.

Bonus: Clear about-to-be-released blocks with a better magic number for better debugging of dangling pointers.

data.title: Strange visual glitch when enabling SSAO or SS Reflections
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:** Windows 10 64Bit - Godot 3.0 Alpha


**Issue description:** This might be a user error on my part but it is quite strange. After enabling either SS Reflections or SSAO when a mesh is present in the scene part of the viewport is white, the mesh simply turns black and the console is being spammed with errors as seen here:
![ssao_glitch](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/18212852/26725421/c890e2e0-479e-11e7-9239-fb8a9e10a92d.png)

`ERROR: _display_error_with_code: SceneShaderGLES3: Fragment Program Compilation Failed:
0(1238) : error C7505: OpenGL does not allow swizzles on scalar expressions
0(1238) : error C7505: OpenGL does not allow swizzles on scalar expressions
0(1238) : error C1031: swizzle mask element not present in operand "g"
0(1238) : error C7505: OpenGL does not allow swizzles on scalar expressions
0(1238) : error C1031: swizzle mask element not present in operand "b"`

  ` At: drivers/gles3/shader_gles3.cpp:167`


`ERROR: _gl_debug_print: GL ERROR: Source: OpenGL        Type: Error     ID: 1282        Severity: High  Message: GL_INVALID_OPERATION error generated. No active program.
   At: drivers/gles3/rasterizer_gles3.cpp:123`

The first error message appears only twice while the other one is being printed constantly while either one or both of the options are enabled. Am I missing something here when it comes to the SS implementation?
I think it appeared shortly after the rewritten PBR implementation got added. As I have seen screenshots from Linux users that did not appear to have this issue I would assume that it is Windows  specific.

**Steps to reproduce:** 
1. Create a new project
2. Add a mesh or just use the TestCube
3. Enable SS Reflections or SSAO

data.title: Strange visual effect when using SS Reflections
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:** Linux, Godot 3 master

This is probably a combination of several factors, so might be hard to track. Take a look at the gif: 
http://i.imgur.com/W811zGQ.gifv

The area right below the hat, in the front and back of the head seems to have a different color, when aligned with the water material (where SSR is stronger). I think it negates the SSR effect and the water looks like the rest where no reflection is present.

extra picture from a different location (harder to see but still visible):
![screenshot from 2017-06-02 12-52-52](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1642015/26724629/6f780c26-4792-11e7-854d-dd71dfabbe39.png)

data.title: Fix Variant::OBJECT token parsing
data.body: Fixes @reduz's new generic Variant:OBJECT parsing code, which also fixes reading/writing input maps from project.godot.  This should resolve #8969.

data.title: Improve reliability of memory stats
data.body:
This PR is two-fold:

### 1) Improve reliability of mem stats

- The allocation count is managed atomically and where it actually should change (for instance, not counting an allocation before its success has been checked).

### 2) Memory block byte-tagging

- Memory just allocated or the portion of memory added to a block with a realloc is initialized with some magic number. _Helps catching bugs about unitialized members._
- Memory about to be freed or the portion of a memory block which is about to disappear by a shrinking realloc is filled with a differnt magic number. _Helps catching bugs due to dangling pointers._

Disabled by default. Can be enabled for debug builds by defining `DEBUG_MEMORY_TAGGING`.

data.title: Compilling for Android from Linux only works once
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
XUbuntu 16.04, Godot 2.1.3

**Issue description:**
<!-- What happened, and what was expected. -->
I tried to compile the export templates with my module and when try to recompile the scons give this message:
```
godot-2.1.3-stable$ scons platform=android target=release -j4
scons: Reading SConscript files ...
sh: 1: i586-mingw32msvc-gcc: not found
sh: 1: i686-w64-mingw32-gcc: not found
No valid target platform selected.
The following were detected:
	x11
	server
	haiku
	windows

Please run scons again with argument: platform=<string>
scons: done reading SConscript files.
scons: Building targets ...
scons: `.' is up to date.
scons: done building targets.

```
But I can compile just once time, and so try to rebuild and nothing works. Someone knows how to procede in this?

**Steps to reproduce:**
Compile once and try to recompile again and fails.

**Link to minimal example project:**
<!-- Optional but very welcome. You can drag and drop a zip archive to upload it. -->

data.title: Texture arrays and 3D textures in shaders
data.body:
I had a discussion with a shader ninja friend about how to properly texture a terrain, and I learned an efficient way to do it is to use texture arrays, or 3D textures, along with a clever use of blend indices, reducing texture fetches from N (any number of textures) to *always* 4, or 8 depending on your setup.
These features are available in GLES3, maybe even in GLES2.

Given that I plan to contribute a terrain module/plugin (and work on related things such as a voxel-based one), is it planned to have texture arrays support or 3D textures in Godot 3.0? Or is it already supported?

(I also thought a Minecrafty terrain would benefit a lot from this because it would fix the limitations of using an atlas, which currently creates seams due to mipmapping)
